chunk:
There are 4 mitigations methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Windows Management Instrumentation, whose names are as follows:
* Privileged Account Management 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* User Account Management 
* Execution Prevention 

This is a mitigation method called Privileged Account Management, its information is as follows:
Description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

This is a mitigation method called Behavior Prevention on Endpoint, its information is as follows:
Description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

This is a mitigation method called User Account Management, its information is as follows:
Description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

This is a mitigation method called Execution Prevention, its information is as follows:
Description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks the execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

chunk: There are 5 sub attack techniques of the attck technique called Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts, whose names are as follows: * RC Scripts * Logon Script (Windows) * Network Logon Script * Startup Items * Login Hook This is an attack technique called Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may use scripts automatically executed at boot or logon initialization to establish persistence.(Citation: Mandiant APT29 Eye Spy Email Nov 22)(Citation: Anomali Rocke March 2019) Initialization scripts can be used to perform administrative functions, which may often execute other programs or send information to an internal logging server. These scripts can vary based on operating system and whether applied locally or remotely. Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a single system. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. An adversary may also be able to escalate their privileges since some boot or logon initialization scripts run with higher privileges. Attack platforms: macOS, Windows, Linux, Network This is an attack technique called RC Scripts, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may establish persistence by modifying RC scripts which are executed during a Unix-like system’s startup. These files allow system administrators to map and start custom services at startup for different run levels. RC scripts require root privileges to modify. Adversaries can establish persistence by adding a malicious binary path or shell commands to rc.local, rc.common, and other RC scripts specific to the Unix-like distribution.(Citation: IranThreats Kittens Dec 2017)(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019) Upon reboot, the system executes the script's contents as root, resulting in persistence. Adversary abuse of RC scripts is especially effective for lightweight Unix-like distributions using the root user as default, such as IoT or embedded systems.(Citation: intezer-kaiji-malware) Several Unix-like systems have moved to Systemd and deprecated the use of RC scripts. This is now a deprecated mechanism in macOS in favor of [Launchd](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053/004). (Citation: Apple Developer Doco Archive Launchd)(Citation: Startup Items) This technique can be used on Mac OS X Panther v10.3 and earlier versions which still execute the RC scripts.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) To maintain backwards compatibility some systems, such as Ubuntu, will execute the RC scripts if they exist with the correct file permissions.(Citation: Ubuntu Manpage systemd rc) Attack platforms: macOS, Linux, Network This is an attack technique called Logon Script (Windows), its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may use Windows logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Windows allows logon scripts to be run whenever a specific user or group of users log into a system.(Citation: TechNet Logon Scripts) This is done via adding a path to a script to the HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript Registry key.(Citation: Hexacorn Logon Scripts) Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a single system. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. Attack platforms: Windows This is an attack technique called Network Logon Script, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may use network logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Network logon scripts can be assigned using Active Directory or Group Policy Objects.(Citation: Petri Logon Script AD) These logon scripts run with the privileges of the user they are assigned to. Depending on the systems within the network, initializing one of these scripts could apply to more than one or potentially all systems. Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a network. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. Attack platforms: Windows This is an attack technique called Startup Items, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may use startup items automatically executed at boot initialization to establish persistence. Startup items execute during the final phase of the boot process and contain shell scripts or other executable files along with configuration information used by the system to determine the execution order for all startup items.(Citation: Startup Items) This is technically a deprecated technology (superseded by [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004)), and thus the appropriate folder, /Library/StartupItems isn’t guaranteed to exist on the system by default, but does appear to exist by default on macOS Sierra. A startup item is a directory whose executable and configuration property list (plist), StartupParameters.plist, reside in the top-level directory. An adversary can create the appropriate folders/files in the StartupItems directory to register their own persistence mechanism.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) Additionally, since StartupItems run during the bootup phase of macOS, they will run as the elevated root user. Attack platforms: macOS This is an attack technique called Login Hook, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may use a Login Hook to establish persistence executed upon user logon. A login hook is a plist file that points to a specific script to execute with root privileges upon user logon. The plist file is located in the /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist file and can be modified using the defaults command-line utility. This behavior is the

entities.name: BOOT OR LOGON INITIALIZATION SCRIPTS
entities.description: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts is an attack technique where scripts are executed at boot or logon to establish persistence on a system.

entities.name: RC SCRIPTS
entities.description: RC Scripts are a type of attack technique used to establish persistence by modifying scripts executed during a Unix-like system's startup.

entities.name: LOGON SCRIPT (WINDOWS)
entities.description: Logon Script (Windows) is an attack technique where scripts are automatically executed at logon initialization to maintain persistence on Windows systems.

entities.name: NETWORK LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Network Logon Script is an attack technique that uses scripts executed at logon initialization to establish persistence across a network.

entities.name: STARTUP ITEMS
entities.description: Startup Items are scripts or executable files that run during the boot process to establish persistence on macOS systems.

entities.name: LOGIN HOOK
entities.description: Login Hook is an attack technique that executes a specific script with root privileges upon user logon to maintain persistence.

entities.name: ANOMALI
entities.description: Anomali is a cybersecurity company that specializes in threat intelligence and analysis, including the monitoring of attack techniques such as Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. that supports various attack techniques, including Startup Items and Login Hooks.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft that allows the use of logon scripts for maintaining persistence.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that supports various attack techniques, including RC Scripts and Network Logon Scripts.

entities.name: UNIX-LIKE SYSTEMS
entities.description: Unix-like systems are operating systems that share similar characteristics and support attack techniques like RC Scripts for establishing persistence.

chunk: This is an attack technique called Login Hook, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may use a Login Hook to establish persistence executed upon user logon. A login hook is a plist file that points to a specific script to execute with root privileges upon user logon. The plist file is located in the /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist file and can be modified using the defaults command-line utility. This behavior is the same for logout hooks where a script can be executed upon user logout. All hooks require administrator permissions to modify or create hooks.(Citation: Login Scripts Apple Dev)(Citation: LoginWindowScripts Apple Dev) Adversaries can add or insert a path to a malicious script in the com.apple.loginwindow.plist file, using the LoginHook or LogoutHook key-value pair. The malicious script is executed upon the next user login. If a login hook already exists, adversaries can add additional commands to an existing login hook. There can be only one login and logout hook on a system at a time.(Citation: S1 macOs Persistence)(Citation: Wardle Persistence Chapter) **Note:** Login hooks were deprecated in 10.11 version of macOS in favor of [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004) and [Launch Agent](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/001) Attack platforms: macOS

entities.name: LOGIN HOOK
entities.description: Login Hook is an attack technique used by adversaries to establish persistence executed upon user logon, involving a plist file that points to a specific script executed with root privileges.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is the operating system where the Login Hook technique can be utilized, specifically noted for its security features and user management.

entities.name: LOGINWINDOWSCRIPTS APPLE DEV
entities.description: LoginWindowScripts Apple Dev is a reference source that provides information about the Login Hook technique and its implementation in macOS.

entities.name: S1 MACOS PERSISTENCE
entities.description: S1 macOS Persistence is a reference source that discusses various persistence techniques on macOS, including the use of Login Hooks.

entities.name: WARDLE PERSISTENCE CHAPTER
entities.description: Wardle Persistence Chapter is a reference source that covers persistence methods on macOS, including the deprecated Login Hooks.

entities.name: LOGOUT HOOK
entities.description: Logout Hook is a similar technique to Login Hook, allowing scripts to be executed upon user logout, also requiring administrator permissions.

entities.name: PLIST FILE
entities.description: The plist file is a configuration file used in macOS that can be modified to include malicious scripts for Login and Logout Hooks.

entities.name: DEFAULTS COMMAND-LINE UTILITY
entities.description: The defaults command-line utility is a tool in macOS used to read and write plist files, which can be exploited to modify Login Hooks.

entities.name: ADMINISTRATOR PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Administrator permissions are required to modify or create Login and Logout Hooks on a macOS system.

key="d1">Login Hook is an attack technique used by adversaries to establish persistence executed upon user logon, involving a plist file that points to a specific script executed with root privileges.</data>      <data key="d2">dd4a69c6cdb460d3c14f38d9630cff6d</data>    </node>    <node id="MACOS">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">macOS is the operating system where id="LOGINWINDOWSCRIPTS APPLE DEV">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">LoginWindowScripts Apple Dev is a reference source that provides information about the Login Hook technique and its implementation in macOS.</data>      <data key="d2">dd4a69c6cdb460d3c14f38d9630cff6d</data>    </node>    <node id="S1 MACOS PERSISTENCE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">S1 macOS Persistence is a reference source that discusses various persistence techniques on macOS, including the use of Login Hooks.</data>      <data HOOK">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Logout Hook is a similar technique to Login Hook, allowing scripts to be executed upon user logout, also requiring administrator chunk:
There are 4 mitigations methods that can mitigating the attack technique called LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay, whose names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 
* Filter Network Traffic 

This is a mitigation method called Disable or Remove Feature or Program, its information is as follows:
Description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

This is a mitigation method called Network Intrusion Prevention, its information is as follows:
Description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

This is a mitigation method called Network Segmentation, its information is as follows:
Description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

This is a mitigation method called Filter Network Traffic, its information is as follows:
Description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning is an attack technique that exploits vulnerabilities in network protocols to intercept and manipulate network traffic.

entities.name: SMB RELAY
entities.description: SMB Relay is an attack technique that allows an attacker to intercept and relay authentication requests to gain unauthorized access to network resources.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: A mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary software to prevent exploitation by adversaries.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: A mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block malicious traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: A mitigation method that involves architecting network sections to isolate critical systems and prevent unauthorized access to sensitive information.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: A mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter traffic and perform protocol-based filtering to enhance security.

entities.name: NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Network traffic refers to the data that is transmitted over a network, which can be monitored and filtered to enhance security.

chunk: There are 3 sub attack techniques of the attck technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle, whose names are as follows: * DHCP Spoofing * ARP Cache Poisoning * LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay This is an attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique to support follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040), [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002), or replay attacks ([Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212)). By abusing features of common networking protocols that can determine the flow of network traffic (e.g. ARP, DNS, LLMNR, etc.), adversaries may force a device to communicate through an adversary controlled system so they can collect information or perform additional actions.(Citation: Rapid7 MiTM Basics) For example, adversaries may manipulate victim DNS settings to enable other malicious activities such as preventing/redirecting users from accessing legitimate sites and/or pushing additional malware.(Citation: ttint_rat)(Citation: dns_changer_trojans)(Citation: ad_blocker_with_miner) Adversaries may also manipulate DNS and leverage their position in order to intercept user credentials, including access tokens ([Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)) and session cookies ([Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)).(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)(Citation: Token tactics) [Downgrade Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/010)s can also be used to establish an AiTM position, such as by negotiating a less secure, deprecated, or weaker version of communication protocol (SSL/TLS) or encryption algorithm.(Citation: mitm_tls_downgrade_att)(Citation: taxonomy_downgrade_att_tls)(Citation: tlseminar_downgrade_att) Adversaries may also leverage the AiTM position to attempt to monitor and/or modify traffic, such as in [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). Adversaries can setup a position similar to AiTM to prevent traffic from flowing to the appropriate destination, potentially to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) and/or in support of a [Network Denial of Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498). Attack platforms: Windows, macOS, Linux, Network This is an attack technique called DHCP Spoofing, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.(Citation: rfc2131) The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 1. The client broadcasts a `DISCOVER` message. 2. The server responds with an `OFFER` message, which includes an available network address. 3. The client broadcasts a `REQUEST` message, which includes the network address offered. 4. The server acknowledges with an `ACK` message and the client receives the network configuration parameters. Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.(Citation: new_rogue_DHCP_serv_malware)(Citation: w32.tidserv.g) Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network. DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a INFORMATION-REQUEST (code 11) message to the All_DHCP_Relay_Agents_and_Servers multicast address.(Citation: rfc3315) Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations. Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, [Service Exhaustion Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002)) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a network’s DHCP allocation pool. Attack platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS This is an attack technique called ARP Cache Poisoning, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used to enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is an attack technique where adversaries position themselves between networked devices to intercept or manipulate communications.

entities.name: DHCP SPOOFING
entities.description: DHCP Spoofing is an attack technique where adversaries spoof DHCP traffic to redirect network traffic to their own systems, allowing them to collect sensitive information.

entities.name: ARP CACHE POISONING
entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is an attack technique where adversaries poison ARP caches to intercept communications between networked devices.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING AND SMB RELAY
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay is an attack technique that allows adversaries to intercept and relay SMB traffic by exploiting LLMNR and NBT-NS protocols.

entities.name: TRANSMITTED DATA MANIPULATION
entities.description: Transmitted Data Manipulation is a follow-on behavior where adversaries alter data being transmitted over the network to achieve malicious objectives.

entities.name: REPLAY ATTACKS
entities.description: Replay Attacks are a type of attack where valid data transmission is maliciously or fraudulently repeated or delayed.

entities.name: EXPLOITATION FOR CREDENTIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Exploitation for Credential Access is an attack technique aimed at obtaining user credentials through various means.

entities.name: STEAL APPLICATION ACCESS TOKEN
entities.description: Steal Application Access Token is a technique where adversaries capture access tokens to gain unauthorized access to applications.

entities.name: STEAL WEB SESSION COOKIE
entities.description: Steal Web Session Cookie is a technique where adversaries capture session cookies to hijack user sessions.

entities.name: DOWGRADE ATTACK
entities.description: Downgrade Attack is a technique where adversaries force a system to use a less secure version of a protocol to exploit vulnerabilities.

entities.name: IMPAIR DEFENSES
entities.description: Impair Defenses is a technique where adversaries disrupt or disable security measures to facilitate their attacks.

entities.name: NETWORK DENIAL OF SERVICE
entities.description: Network Denial of Service is an attack aimed at making a network resource unavailable to its intended users.

Attack platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

 This is an attack technique called ARP Cache Poisoning, its information is as follows:
Description: Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used to enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002).

The ARP protocol is used to resolve IPv4 addresses to link layer addresses, such as a media access control (MAC) address.(Citation: RFC826 ARP) Devices in a local network segment communicate with each other by using link layer addresses. If a networked device does not have the link layer address of a particular networked device, it may send out a broadcast ARP request to the local network to translate the IP address to a MAC address. The device with the associated IP address directly replies with its MAC address. The networked device that made the ARP request will then use as well as store that information in its ARP cache.

An adversary may passively wait for an ARP request to poison the ARP cache of the requesting device. The adversary may reply with their MAC address, thus deceiving the victim by making them believe that they are communicating with the intended networked device. For the adversary to poison the ARP cache, their reply must be faster than the one made by the legitimate IP address owner. Adversaries may also send a gratuitous ARP reply that maliciously announces the ownership of a particular IP address to all the devices in the local network segment.

The ARP protocol is stateless and does not require authentication. Therefore, devices may wrongly add or update the MAC address of the IP address in their ARP cache.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

Adversaries may use ARP cache poisoning as a means to intercept network traffic. This activity may be used to collect and/or relay data such as credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)

Attack platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

 This is an attack technique called LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay, its information is as follows:
Description: By responding to LLMNR/NBT-NS network traffic, adversaries may spoof an authoritative source for name resolution to force communication with an adversary controlled system. This activity may be used to collect or relay authentication materials. 

Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR) and NetBIOS Name Service (NBT-NS) are Microsoft Windows components that serve as alternate methods of host identification. LLMNR is based upon the Domain Name System (DNS) format and allows hosts on the same local link to perform name resolution for other hosts. NBT-NS identifies systems on a local network by their NetBIOS name. (Citation: Wikipedia LLMNR)(Citation: TechNet NetBIOS)

Adversaries can spoof an authoritative source for name resolution on a victim network by responding to LLMNR (UDP 5355)/NBT-NS (UDP 137) traffic as if they know the identity of the requested host, effectively poisoning the service so that the victims will communicate with the adversary controlled system. If the requested host belongs to a resource that requires identification/authentication, the username and NTLMv2 hash will then be sent to the adversary controlled system. The adversary can then collect the hash information sent over the wire through tools that monitor the ports for traffic or through [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) and crack the hashes offline through [Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) to obtain the plaintext passwords.

In some cases where an adversary has access to a system that is in the authentication path between systems or when automated scans that use credentials attempt to authenticate to an adversary controlled system, the NTLMv1/v2 hashes can be intercepted and relayed to access and execute code against a target system. The relay step can happen in conjunction with poisoning but may also be independent of it.(Citation: byt3bl33d3r NTLM Relaying)(Citation: Secure Ideas SMB Relay) Additionally, adversaries may encapsulate the NTLMv1/v2 hashes into various protocols, such as LDAP, SMB, MSSQL and HTTP, to expand and use multiple services with the valid NTLM response. 

Several tools may be used to poison name services within local networks such as NBNSpoof, Metasploit, and [Responder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0174).(Citation: GitHub NBNSpoof)(Citation: Rapid7 LLMNR Spoofer)(Citation: GitHub Responder)
Attack platforms: Windows

entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is an attack technique where adversaries poison Address Resolution Protocol caches to intercept communication between networked devices.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning is an attack technique that allows adversaries to spoof name resolution to force communication with their controlled systems.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that can be targeted by various network attacks including ARP Cache Poisoning and LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that is susceptible to attacks such as LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can also be targeted by ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: NETWORK SNIFFING
entities.description: Network Sniffing is a technique used by adversaries to intercept and analyze network traffic, often to collect sensitive information such as credentials.

entities.name: TRANSMITTED DATA MANIPULATION
entities.description: Transmitted Data Manipulation refers to the act of altering data being sent over a network, which can be a follow-on behavior of ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: NTLMV1
entities.description: NTLMv1 is a challenge-response authentication protocol used in Windows networks, which can be intercepted and relayed by adversaries.

entities.name: NTLMV2
entities.description: NTLMv2 is an improved version of NTLMv1, providing better security for authentication in Windows networks, but can still be exploited by adversaries.

entities.name: LDAP
entities.description: Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is a protocol used to access and manage directory information services, which can be targeted during network attacks.

entities.name: SMB
entities.description: Server Message Block (SMB) is a network file sharing protocol that can be exploited during attacks such as NTLM relay attacks.

entities.name: MSSQL
entities.description: Microsoft SQL Server (MSSQL) is a relational database management system that can be targeted during network attacks involving NTLM authentication.

There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attck technique called Windows Management Instrumentation, whose names are as follows:

 This is an attack technique called Windows Management Instrumentation, its information is as follows:
Description: Adversaries may abuse Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute malicious commands and payloads. WMI is designed for programmers and is the infrastructure for management data and operations on Windows systems.(Citation: WMI 1-3) WMI is an administration feature that provides a uniform environment to access Windows system components.

The WMI service enables both local and remote access, though the latter is facilitated by [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Windows Remote Management](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/006).(Citation: WMI 1-3) Remote WMI over DCOM operates using port 135, whereas WMI over WinRM operates over port 5985 when using HTTP and 5986 for HTTPS.(Citation: WMI 1-3) (Citation: Mandiant WMI)

An adversary can use WMI to interact with local and remote systems and use it as a means to execute various behaviors, such as gathering information for [Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0007) as well as [Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002) of commands and payloads.(Citation: Mandiant WMI) For example, `wmic.exe` can be abused by an adversary to delete shadow copies with the command `wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete` (i.e., [Inhibit System Recovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1490)).(Citation: WMI 6)

**Note:** `wmic.exe` is deprecated as of January of 2024, with the WMIC feature being “disabled by default” on Windows 11+. WMIC will be removed from subsequent Windows releases and replaced by [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) as the primary WMI interface.(Citation: WMI 7,8) In addition to PowerShell and tools like `wbemtool.exe`, COM APIs can also be used to programmatically interact with WMI via C++, .NET, VBScript, etc.(Citation: WMI 7,8)
Attack platforms: Windows

entities.name: WINDOWS MANAGEMENT INSTRUMENTATION
entities.description: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) is an attack technique that adversaries may abuse to execute malicious commands and payloads on Windows systems.

entities.name: WMIC
entities.description: WMIC is a command-line utility that can be abused by adversaries to delete shadow copies and execute various commands, but it is deprecated as of January 2024.

entities.name: WINDOWS 11
entities.description: Windows 11 is an operating system that will disable WMIC by default and will not include it in future releases.

entities.name: POWERSELL
entities.description: PowerShell is the primary WMI interface that will replace WMIC in subsequent Windows releases.

entities.name: REMOTE SERVICES
entities.description: Remote Services facilitate remote access to WMI, allowing adversaries to execute commands on remote systems.

entities.name: DCOM
entities.description: Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) is a protocol that allows remote access to WMI services.

entities.name: WINRM
entities.description: Windows Remote Management (WinRM) is a service that allows for remote management of Windows systems and operates over specific ports for WMI access.

entities.name: C++
entities.description: C++ is a programming language that can be used to interact with WMI through COM APIs.

entities.name: VBSCRIPT
entities.description: VBScript is a scripting language that can also be used to programmatically interact with WMI.

entities.name: NET
entities.description: NET is a framework that can be used to interact with WMI via programming.

entities.name: MALICIOUS COMMANDS
entities.description: Malicious commands are harmful instructions that adversaries can execute using WMI to compromise systems.

entities.name: PAYLOADS
entities.description: Payloads refer to the malicious software or scripts that adversaries may deploy using WMI to achieve their objectives.

entities.name: SHADOW COPIES
entities.description: Shadow copies are backup copies of files that can be deleted by adversaries using commands executed through WMIC.

entities.name: ADMINISTRATION FEATURE
entities.description: WMI serves as an administration feature that provides a uniform environment to access Windows system components.

entities.name: MANAGEMENT DATA
entities.description: Management data refers to the information that WMI can access and manipulate on Windows systems.

entities.name: WINDOWS SYSTEMS
entities.description: Windows systems are the operating systems that utilize WMI for management and operations.

chunk:
There are 2 mitigations methods that can mitigating the attack technique called DHCP Spoofing, whose names are as follows:
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 

This is a mitigation method called Filter Network Traffic, its information is as follows:
Description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

This is a mitigation method called Network Intrusion Prevention, its information is as follows:
Description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: NETWORK APPLIANCES
entities.description: Network appliances are hardware devices used to manage and filter network traffic, often employed in security measures.

entities.name: SOFTWARE
entities.description: Software on endpoints is used to filter network traffic and enhance security by implementing various filtering protocols.

chunk: There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attck technique called Screen Capture, whose names are as follows: This is an attack technique called Screen Capture, its information is as follows: Description: Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation. Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations. Taking a screenshot is also typically possible through native utilities or API calls, such as CopyFromScreen, xwd, or screencapture.(Citation: CopyFromScreen .NET)(Citation: Antiquated Mac Malware) Attack platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

entities.name: SCREEN CAPTURE
entities.description: Screen Capture is an attack technique where adversaries take screenshots of the desktop to gather information during an operation.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform where the Screen Capture attack technique can be executed.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform where the Screen Capture attack technique can be executed.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform where the Screen Capture attack technique can be executed.

entities.name: COPYFROMSCREEN
entities.description: CopyFromScreen is a method in .NET used to capture the screen, which can be utilized in the Screen Capture attack technique.

entities.name: XWD
entities.description: xwd is a command-line utility in Unix-like operating systems used to capture the screen, relevant to the Screen Capture attack technique.

entities.name: SCREENCAPTURE
entities.description: screencapture is a command used in macOS to take screenshots, applicable in the context of the Screen Capture attack technique.

There are 1 mitigations methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Startup Items, whose names are as follows:
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

This is a mitigation method called Restrict File and Directory Permissions, its information is as follows:
Description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method aimed at enhancing security by controlling access to files and directories through permission settings.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigations methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Scheduled Task, whose names are as follows:
* Privileged Account Management 
* User Account Management 
* Audit 
* Operating System Configuration 

This is a mitigation method called Privileged Account Management, its information is as follows:
Description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

This is a mitigation method called User Account Management, its information is as follows:
Description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

This is a mitigation method called Audit, its information is as follows:
Description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

This is a mitigation method called Operating System Configuration, its information is as follows:
Description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

This is a mitigation method called Limit Software Installation, its information is as follows:

There are 6 mitigations methods that can mitigating the attack technique called ARP Cache Poisoning, whose names are as follows:
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* User Training 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Filter Network Traffic 

This is a mitigation method called Encrypt Sensitive Information, its information is as follows:
Description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

This is a mitigation method called Network Intrusion Prevention, its information is as follows:
Description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

This is a mitigation method called User Training, its information is as follows:
Description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

chunk:
There are 7 mitigations methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle, whose names are as follows:
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* User Training 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 

This is a mitigation method called Filter Network Traffic, its information is as follows:
Description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

This is a mitigation method called Encrypt Sensitive Information, its information is as follows:
Description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

This is a mitigation method called Limit Access to Resource Over Network, its information is as follows:
Description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

This is a mitigation method called Disable or Remove Feature or Program, its information is as follows:
Description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

This is a mitigation method called User Training, its information is as follows:
Description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

This is a mitigation method called Network Intrusion Prevention, its information is as follows:
Description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

This is a mitigation method called Network Segmentation, its information is as follows:
Description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.
